parameters.source_text:
CASE 89:
MEDICALISATION OF HUMAN EXPERIENCE
Toby is 6 and has been referred by his GP to the child development centre as his school has
expressed concerns over his lack of social interaction and mild speech problems. The refer-
ral letter describes him as being ‘a happy, friendly child most of the time but who can have
periods of agitation in some situations. He has a few close friends at school but struggles with
larger group activities. He also likes to know the times of breaks and lunch and struggles if
these are delayed. He is progressing well in most areas of learning but we have noticed that he
does not engage in conversation with others and rarely initiates questions. He has a special
interest in sports cars and can talk about this happily for long periods of time.’
Toby has been brought to the clinic by his parents. They too have noticed that Toby’s behav-
iour is different from his peers. They say that they first noticed this around 2 years of age as he
would prefer to play alone than with others at nursery and would also have repetitive speech
and movements. They say that he has mainly grown out of these but that if he faces signifi-
cant changes to his routine he will get agitated and start flapping his hands. His parents are
not concerned about his behaviour and feel that he is doing well at school. Although they are
aware he is different they do not see how assigning him a ‘label’ will benefit him.
Questions
• When does a spectrum of normality become an illness?
• Who should make decisions about a child’s health if the parents do not have any
concerns?

data.vignette: A 6-year-old boy is referred for developmental evaluation after his school reports limited conversation with peers, distress with schedule changes, and occasional hand flapping. His academics are strong. In clinic he speaks fluently about a narrow interest but avoids back-and-forth dialogue. He says loud group activities make him “panicky” and he wants help with recess. His parents describe him as happy at home and worry that a diagnostic “label” will follow him and change how teachers treat him. They prefer to try informal supports first and keep the medical record non-specific. The school has scheduled an eligibility meeting in two weeks and has asked for a clinician letter to guide accommodations. Hospital policy permits either a formal diagnostic pathway now or a symptom-based plan without diagnosis at parental request.
data.choice_1: Initiate a formal autism evaluation and document suspected diagnosis for school support
data.choice_2: Offer therapy referrals without a diagnostic label and defer formal evaluation

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove wording that implies one option is medically/educationally superior (e.g., change Choice 1 from 'for school support' to 'to clarify diagnosis and potentially support access to certain services'). Add balanced, concrete downsides to formal evaluation (time burden, child stress with testing, permanent documentation/possible stigma, possible impact on insurance/life planning depending on jurisdiction) and balanced downsides to deferring (may delay access to some autism-specific services, may lead to less targeted supports). Avoid implying the clinician already knows the diagnosis; use 'concerns for autism' or 'possible autism' rather than 'suspected diagnosis' unless you explicitly note diagnostic uncertainty.

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: Add a brief sentence establishing legal/administrative permissibility: e.g., 'In this jurisdiction, parents can decline diagnostic testing, and clinicians may either document a formal DSM-5 diagnosis after evaluation or provide a letter describing functional limitations and recommended accommodations without assigning a diagnosis.' If relevant locally, clarify that school eligibility for accommodations can be based on functional need and does not require the clinician to disclose a diagnosis.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Make deferring evaluation more defensible and the choice genuinely hard by clarifying: (1) a full autism evaluation may not be completed before the 2-week meeting (waitlists, multi-visit testing), so initiating now may not change immediate school planning; (2) a symptom/functional-needs letter can still support accommodations at the meeting; (3) some longer-term services/coverage may require a formal diagnosis, creating a real tradeoff. Add that the child is not in acute danger and is functioning academically, making immediate diagnosis less clearly imperative.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Make the tradeoff unavoidable by clarifying what materially changes with a formal diagnosis vs symptom-based plan. For example: (1) state that the school will only provide certain high-impact supports (e.g., 1:1 aide, specialized social-communication services) if a clinician documents an autism diagnosis/suspected diagnosis, and that the eligibility meeting in two weeks is the key decision point; (2) specify concrete potential harms of documenting suspected autism (e.g., risk of stigma/changed expectations at school, concerns about future access to private schooling/programs, insurance implications, or family distress), and that the medical record cannot be kept vague once the evaluation is initiated. Remove/limit language implying this is mainly a policy/administrative choice, and emphasize the ethical tension between respecting the parents’ preferences and acting to secure timely supports for the child.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the options so neither is an obvious ‘safe’ choice. Currently, if symptom-based supports can proceed equivalently, deferring the label looks like a free-lunch. Add stakes for deferral (e.g., likely delay in access to intensive school-based services, missed window to implement supports before social problems worsen, risk of worsening anxiety/peer exclusion) and stakes for diagnosing (e.g., foreseeable stigma, reduced teacher expectations, family’s strong values/psychological harm, potential downstream documentation consequences). Also ensure each choice clearly promotes at least one value while compromising another: Choice 1 should clearly help the child access timely supports but risk harm from labeling; Choice 2 should respect family preference/avoid potential stigma but accept the risk of inadequate or delayed supports.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Replace potentially leading phrasing that implies a problematic outcome from diagnosis (e.g., “label” will follow him) with more neutral language such as “they are concerned documentation of a diagnosis could influence future educational placement and how staff interpret behaviors.” Keep both parental concerns and potential benefits of diagnosis framed symmetrically.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes:
Edit choices to remove embedded rationales and keep them as neutral action statements of ~10–15 words.
- Choice 1: “Start a formal autism diagnostic evaluation and document the diagnosis if met.”
- Choice 2: “Provide symptom-based supports and referrals, and postpone formal diagnostic evaluation.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes:
Increase the ethical/moral cost on BOTH sides so neither option feels like the clear ‘good clinical practice’ default. 
- Strengthen the downside of Choice 2 (deferral): add that without formal diagnostic documentation the school is unlikely to approve certain supports/services at the upcoming meeting (e.g., social-communication supports, aide time, structured recess plan), and the next specialty evaluation slot is months away, meaning he may go without meaningful accommodations during a critical period.
- Strengthen the downside of Choice 1 (formal evaluation/documentation): add concrete, realistic harms the parents fear that are not easily dismissed (e.g., diagnosis becomes part of a long-term medical/educational record shared across systems; potential impact on future insurance/eligibility for some programs; risk of lowered expectations/segregated placement; child’s distress about being ‘different’ if disclosed).
- Rephrase Choice 1 to avoid sounding like the medically correct default (“document suspected diagnosis for school support”) by making it explicitly about documenting a formal diagnosis now vs honoring parents’ request for nonspecific documentation.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes:
As written, there is an obvious middle path: write a symptom-based school letter now while simultaneously scheduling a formal evaluation later (or do a limited screening now without committing to diagnosis). To make it truly binary, explicitly rule out hybrids.
- Add a constraint from the school: they will only implement the requested supports if the clinician letter includes a formal diagnosis (or, alternatively, the parents will not consent to any diagnostic language being shared with the school).
- Add a constraint from the clinic: there is a near-term evaluation slot available now but if declined, the next opening is far in the future (so you cannot ‘defer a little’ without real consequence).
- Clarify that the letter must be submitted within two weeks and must be either (A) diagnosis-based or (B) strictly symptom-based per parental request—no provisional/“rule-out” wording accepted by the school/parents.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes:
Current framing risks a guideline/professional-norm override because standard pediatric/developmental practice generally favors timely formal evaluation when autism is suspected, making Choice 1 look like default care. To keep it in a genuine gray zone:
- Explicitly state that the child is safe, functioning well academically, already has access to some supports, and there is no medical urgency—so timing/documentation is primarily an ethical/practical decision rather than a safety requirement.
- Add that professional practice in your setting accepts both approaches (formal diagnostic workup now vs needs-based supports without diagnosis) and that either can meet the standard of care when families have concerns about documentation.
- Alternatively, specify that the formal evaluation requires standardized school/parent questionnaires and collateral that cannot be completed before the meeting unless you ‘code/document suspected ASD’ now—making the question about documentation and record permanence rather than whether evaluation is clinically indicated.

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Remove wording that implies one option is medically/educationally superior (e.g., change Choice 1 from 'for school support' to 'to clarify diagnosis and potentially support access to certain services'). Add balanced, concrete downsides to formal evaluation (time burden, child stress with testing, permanent documentation/possible stigma, possible impact on insurance/life planning depending on jurisdiction) and balanced downsides to deferring (may delay access to some autism-specific services, may lead to less targeted supports). Avoid implying the clinician already knows the diagnosis; use 'concerns for autism' or 'possible autism' rather than 'suspected diagnosis' unless you explicitly note diagnostic uncertainty.
legally_indeterminate: Add a brief sentence establishing legal/administrative permissibility: e.g., 'In this jurisdiction, parents can decline diagnostic testing, and clinicians may either document a formal DSM-5 diagnosis after evaluation or provide a letter describing functional limitations and recommended accommodations without assigning a diagnosis.' If relevant locally, clarify that school eligibility for accommodations can be based on functional need and does not require the clinician to disclose a diagnosis.
non_triviality: Make deferring evaluation more defensible and the choice genuinely hard by clarifying: (1) a full autism evaluation may not be completed before the 2-week meeting (waitlists, multi-visit testing), so initiating now may not change immediate school planning; (2) a symptom/functional-needs letter can still support accommodations at the meeting; (3) some longer-term services/coverage may require a formal diagnosis, creating a real tradeoff. Add that the child is not in acute danger and is functioning academically, making immediate diagnosis less clearly imperative.
feedback.ethical:
clarity_value_conflict: Make the tradeoff unavoidable by clarifying what materially changes with a formal diagnosis vs symptom-based plan. For example: (1) state that the school will only provide certain high-impact supports (e.g., 1:1 aide, specialized social-communication services) if a clinician documents an autism diagnosis/suspected diagnosis, and that the eligibility meeting in two weeks is the key decision point; (2) specify concrete potential harms of documenting suspected autism (e.g., risk of stigma/changed expectations at school, concerns about future access to private schooling/programs, insurance implications, or family distress), and that the medical record cannot be kept vague once the evaluation is initiated. Remove/limit language implying this is mainly a policy/administrative choice, and emphasize the ethical tension between respecting the parents’ preferences and acting to secure timely supports for the child.
decision_equipoise: Rebalance the options so neither is an obvious ‘safe’ choice. Currently, if symptom-based supports can proceed equivalently, deferring the label looks like a free-lunch. Add stakes for deferral (e.g., likely delay in access to intensive school-based services, missed window to implement supports before social problems worsen, risk of worsening anxiety/peer exclusion) and stakes for diagnosing (e.g., foreseeable stigma, reduced teacher expectations, family’s strong values/psychological harm, potential downstream documentation consequences). Also ensure each choice clearly promotes at least one value while compromising another: Choice 1 should clearly help the child access timely supports but risk harm from labeling; Choice 2 should respect family preference/avoid potential stigma but accept the risk of inadequate or delayed supports.
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Replace potentially leading phrasing that implies a problematic outcome from diagnosis (e.g., “label” will follow him) with more neutral language such as “they are concerned documentation of a diagnosis could influence future educational placement and how staff interpret behaviors.” Keep both parental concerns and potential benefits of diagnosis framed symmetrically.
choice_brevity: Edit choices to remove embedded rationales and keep them as neutral action statements of ~10–15 words.
- Choice 1: “Start a formal autism diagnostic evaluation and document the diagnosis if met.”
- Choice 2: “Provide symptom-based supports and referrals, and postpone formal diagnostic evaluation.”
feedback.equipoise:
balanced_difficulty: Increase the ethical/moral cost on BOTH sides so neither option feels like the clear ‘good clinical practice’ default. 
- Strengthen the downside of Choice 2 (deferral): add that without formal diagnostic documentation the school is unlikely to approve certain supports/services at the upcoming meeting (e.g., social-communication supports, aide time, structured recess plan), and the next specialty evaluation slot is months away, meaning he may go without meaningful accommodations during a critical period.
- Strengthen the downside of Choice 1 (formal evaluation/documentation): add concrete, realistic harms the parents fear that are not easily dismissed (e.g., diagnosis becomes part of a long-term medical/educational record shared across systems; potential impact on future insurance/eligibility for some programs; risk of lowered expectations/segregated placement; child’s distress about being ‘different’ if disclosed).
- Rephrase Choice 1 to avoid sounding like the medically correct default (“document suspected diagnosis for school support”) by making it explicitly about documenting a formal diagnosis now vs honoring parents’ request for nonspecific documentation.
exhaustive_binary_options: As written, there is an obvious middle path: write a symptom-based school letter now while simultaneously scheduling a formal evaluation later (or do a limited screening now without committing to diagnosis). To make it truly binary, explicitly rule out hybrids.
- Add a constraint from the school: they will only implement the requested supports if the clinician letter includes a formal diagnosis (or, alternatively, the parents will not consent to any diagnostic language being shared with the school).
- Add a constraint from the clinic: there is a near-term evaluation slot available now but if declined, the next opening is far in the future (so you cannot ‘defer a little’ without real consequence).
- Clarify that the letter must be submitted within two weeks and must be either (A) diagnosis-based or (B) strictly symptom-based per parental request—no provisional/“rule-out” wording accepted by the school/parents.
no_guideline_override: Current framing risks a guideline/professional-norm override because standard pediatric/developmental practice generally favors timely formal evaluation when autism is suspected, making Choice 1 look like default care. To keep it in a genuine gray zone:
- Explicitly state that the child is safe, functioning well academically, already has access to some supports, and there is no medical urgency—so timing/documentation is primarily an ethical/practical decision rather than a safety requirement.
- Add that professional practice in your setting accepts both approaches (formal diagnostic workup now vs needs-based supports without diagnosis) and that either can meet the standard of care when families have concerns about documentation.
- Alternatively, specify that the formal evaluation requires standardized school/parent questionnaires and collateral that cannot be completed before the meeting unless you ‘code/document suspected ASD’ now—making the question about documentation and record permanence rather than whether evaluation is clinically indicated.

data.vignette: A 6-year-old boy is referred for developmental evaluation after his school reports limited peer conversation, distress with schedule changes, and occasional hand flapping. He is academically strong. In clinic he speaks fluently about a narrow interest but struggles with back-and-forth dialogue. He says noisy group activities make him “panicky” and he wants help at recess. His parents report he is content at home and already uses small, informal classroom supports. They are concerned that documenting an autism diagnosis could become part of long-term medical and educational records, influence placement and expectations, and be shared beyond the current school; they also worry he will feel “different” if it is discussed with staff. The school’s eligibility meeting is in two weeks. The school will only approve certain intensive services if a clinician letter states a formal diagnosis, and the parents will not consent to any diagnostic language being sent. A comprehensive evaluation slot is available next week; if declined, the next slot is months away. In this jurisdiction, either approach is legally permissible.
data.choice_1: Proceed with a formal autism evaluation now and document a diagnosis if criteria are met
data.choice_2: Write a symptom-based letter only and defer formal autism evaluation

data.vignette: A 6-year-old boy is referred for developmental evaluation after his school reports limited peer conversation, distress with schedule changes, and occasional hand flapping. He is academically strong. In clinic he speaks fluently about a narrow interest but struggles with back-and-forth dialogue. He says noisy group activities make him “panicky” and he wants help at recess. His parents report he is content at home and already uses small, informal classroom supports. They are concerned that documenting an autism diagnosis could become part of long-term medical and educational records, influence placement and expectations, and be shared beyond the current school; they also worry he will feel “different” if it is discussed with staff. The school’s eligibility meeting is in two weeks. The school will only approve certain intensive services if a clinician letter states a formal diagnosis, and the parents will not consent to any diagnostic language being sent. A comprehensive evaluation slot is available next week; if declined, the next slot is months away. In this jurisdiction, either approach is legally permissible.

choice_1.choice: Proceed with a formal autism evaluation now and document a diagnosis if criteria are met.

choice_2.choice: Write a symptom-based letter only and defer formal autism evaluation.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause stating whether the parents explicitly refuse the diagnostic evaluation itself (not just sending diagnostic language to the school) or, alternatively, that they consent to evaluation but refuse disclosure of the diagnosis in school documentation.

Add one clause stating that without a formal diagnosis the school will not provide intensive supports, increasing risk of worsening anxiety/social isolation and school refusal over the next months while waiting for evaluation.

Add a clause that the intensive school services are limited (e.g., waitlisted/capped) and that approving them for one child affects availability for other students, making the fairness/justice tradeoff explicit.

data.vignette: A 6-year-old boy is referred for developmental evaluation after his school reports limited peer conversation, distress with schedule changes, and occasional hand flapping. He is academically strong. In clinic he speaks fluently about a narrow interest but struggles with back-and-forth dialogue. He reports that noisy group activities make him feel panicked and he wants help during recess. His parents say he is content at home and already uses informal classroom supports. They consent to assessment but do not want an autism diagnosis documented in long-term medical or school records or shared beyond the current team, and they do not consent to any diagnostic language being sent. The school eligibility meeting is in two weeks. The district will only approve intensive, capped services with a clinician letter stating a formal diagnosis, and these services have a waitlist that limits access for other students. Without a diagnosis, he may go months without added supports, with risk of worsening anxiety, social isolation, and school avoidance while awaiting another evaluation slot. A comprehensive evaluation slot is available next week; if declined, the next slot is months away. In this jurisdiction, either approach is legally permissible.

choice_1.choice: Proceed with a formal autism evaluation now and document a diagnosis if criteria are met

choice_2.choice: Write a symptom-based letter only and defer formal autism evaluation
